article.headline: Packed house watches BC stay perfect
article.story:
BOSTON (AP) -- Craig Smith bulled down the lane and barreled along the baseline.
BC's longest win streaks
Season Streak
2004-05 19*
1968-69 19
1964-65 14
*Best start in school history.
The burly forward bided his time early against swarming defenders, then attacked the basket and led No. 5 Boston College to a 62-50 victory over West Virginia on Tuesday night. His 23 points -- and the Eagles' solid defense in the second half -- helped them to remain one of Division I's two unbeaten teams, but they haven't been distracted by that distinction. "We weren't upset when we weren't being talked about," coach Al Skinner said, "so we're not going to get overly happy when people do talk about us." Boston College (19-0, 8-0 Big East) matched its school record 19-game winning streak set in 1968-69. It already has its highest ranking and best start ever. Only top-ranked Illinois (22-0), which beat Michigan State (No. 10 ESPN/USA Today; No. 12 AP) 81-68 on Tuesday night, has a better record. BC struggled early, missing its first six shots, and Smith was scoreless while the Mountaineers built an 18-9 lead with 9:21 left in the first half. "It's pretty much that way every game," he said. "I have to be patient." Then, with a quick first step, he overpowered the defense. He scored 17 of the Eagles' next 24 points and gave them the lead for good, 33-32, with a layup with 16:04 remaining. "Craig Smith is a load to handle inside," West Virginia's Mike Gansey said. "We tried to double-team him, but that didn't work." Gansey and Tyrone Sally each had 10 points for the Mountaineers (12-7, 2-6), who have lost six of seven, including a 20-point loss at home to BC on Jan. 16. For the first time since February 2001, the Eagles played before a third consecutive capacity crowd at home. But that didn't help at the start as they forced up outside shots while the Mountaineers surrounded the 250-pound Smith. "West Virginia's a very difficult team to play," Skinner said. "They give you a number of different looks on offense and, defensively, it takes time to figure it out." The Eagles scored only on three 3-pointers in their first 12 shots. But Smith got going and so did BC's defense, which held West Virginia scoreless on its last seven shots of the half. The Mountaineers just couldn't handle BC's defense that combines elements of a man-to-man and zone defense on the same play. "You either have to have real quickness outside or be strong inside," West Virginia coach John Beilein said, "and we're not either." Trailing 23-15, Smith scored five straight points, sparking a 10-0 run that gave the Eagles a 25-23 halftime lead. West Virginia went ahead 28-25 on Gansey's 3-pointer and Johannes Herber's basket on a goaltending call. Then Smith took control, scoring the Eagles' next eight points and giving them a 33-32 lead. They never trailed again despite their lowest-scoring game of the season. Their previous low was a 63-60 overtime win over Holy Cross on Dec. 9 . Smith began his run with a three-point play and followed with a dunk, a free throw and a driving layup. Once his teammates found a way to feed him the ball inside, even four defenders who surrounded him on one play couldn't stop him. West Virginia did cut the lead to 42-38 on Gansey's two free throws with 8:27 remaining, but the Eagles went on a 12-3 run that made it 54-41 with 3:10 to go. Jared Dudley, who scored 15 points, and Jermaine Watson, who had 13, each had four points in the run. "Defensively, we really settled down, particularly the last 12 minutes," Skinner said. The surprising Eagles can reach another milestone with a win on Saturday night at Seton Hall that would make them the first Big East team to start a season 20-0.

statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).
